notesStmt.note: In the 17th and 18th centuries in Rome, the festivities of the Carnival often included puppet plays, many of which were set on the piazza Navona, or in its immediate vicinity. Some of these, meant for a popular audience, were staged outside or in temporary boxes; but aristocratic houses could accommodate, on miniature stages, sung performances using string or rod puppets. This was the case for instance of the Teatro de’ Granari, owned by the Pamphili family; most notably, Pulcinella speziale in villa (Pulcinella apothecary in the villa) and Pulcinella guardiano de' pazzarelli (Pulcinella keeper of the insane) were performed on this stage.Pulcinella speziale in villa is an anonymous play built on the model of Lo Speziale di villa, a melodramma by Giovanni Cosimo Villifranchi, staged in 1683 on music by Giovanni Maria Pagliardi, then in 1719 at the Teatro del Cocomero in Florence, and republished several times during the first third of the 18th century. Pulcinella speziale in villa reworks it, dividing it into three acts. The libretto bears the words “dramma giocoso per musica, da rappresentarsi con figurine” (happy drama in music, to be performed with figurines). It seems to have been accompanied with music by Luca Antonio Predieri: as in other drammi per musica for puppets, which were fashionable at the end of the 17th century and at the beginning of the 18th, singers performed behind the stage while puppets were manipulated on it. The characters shown alongside Pulcinella are typical of the commedia dell’arte: Cannetella, described as a Neapolitan woman, speaks her local dialect, just like her master. Contrasting this couple, Delmira speaks the formal language of lofty comedies; however, her cross-dressing leads to a series of comical misunderstandings as it attracts Cannetella’s love. Rosaura’s osculation scenes also lead to a series of misunderstandings and to double meanings typical of baroque comedy.

normalization.p: The semi-diplomatic norms applied are intended to guide and facilitate the reading of the original texts. The transcriptions therefore include spelling and grammatical corrections according to current standards.
The author's orthographic and grammatical corrections have been integrated into the text without being marked. Cuts for performance purposes have not been adopted in the transcription.
Syntax has been modernised where it is naturally incorrect or has become incomprehensible today. Additions are limited and indicated by square brackets.
The copyist's obvious errors (scene numbers, character attributions, etc.) have been corrected. The list of characters could also be corrected.

projectDesc.p: Text collected during the PuppetPlays project funded by European Union (Grant Agreement 835193) under Horizon 2020. The PuppetPlays project aims to re-evaluate the contribution of the puppets repertoire to the construction of European cultural identity. Its main goals is to collect a corpus of representative plays from Western Europe (Germany, Austria, Belgium, Spain, France, Great Britain, Italy, Netherlands, Portugal, Switzerland) between the 17th and the 21th century. It also tries to identify the characteristics of puppet dramaturgy and their variations depending on eras, cultural spheres, producing conditions, and the aimed public.
This edition is the result of university research work, reviewed by the principal investigator.
